column1: Traces of human presence in the area date from the upper Neolithic
column2: and humans have inhabited Jerez de la Frontera since at least the Copper or Neolithic Age
column3: but the identity of the first natives remains unclear.  The first major protohistoric settlement in the area (around the third millennium BC) is attributed to the Tartessians. Jerez later became a Roman city under the name of Asta Regia.

column1: After the fall of the Western Roman Empire
column2: the Vandals and the Visigoths ruled it until the Arabs conquered the area in 711. In the 11th century it briefly became the seat of an independent taifa. Some years later 'Abdun ibn Muhammad united it with Arcos and ruled both (ca. 1040-1053). In 1053 it was annexed to Seville. From 1145 to 1147 the region of Arcos and Jerez briefly operated as an emirate under dependency of Granada
column3: led by Abu'l-Qasim Ahyal. Later the Almohads conquered the city. In the 12th and 13th centuries Jerez underwent a period of great development
column4: building its defense system and setting the current street layout of the old town.

column1: In 1231 the Battle of Jerez took place within the town's vicinity: Christian troops under the command of Álvaro Pérez de Castro
column2: lord of the House of Castro and grandson of Alfonso VII
column3: king of Castile and León
column4: defeated the troops of the Emir Ibn Hud
column5: despite the numerical superiority of the latter. After a month-long siege in 1261
column7: but its Muslim population remained. It rebelled and was finally defeated in 1264.

column1: The discovery of the Americas and the conquest of Granada
column3: made Jerez one of the most prosperous cities of Andalusia through trade and through its proximity to the ports of Seville and Cádiz. Despite the social
column4: economic and political decadence that occurred in the seventeenth century
column5: towards the end of the Habsburg rule
column6: the city managed to maintain a reasonable pace of development
column7: becoming world-famous for its wine industry.

column1: Jerez de la Frontera and the rest of the Cádiz metropolitan area has a Subtropical–Mediterranean climate
column2: yet for its situation being inland (specially the airport which is more inland than the city) the Atlantic influences are small
column3: it is characterized by mild
column4: short winters with occasional cool nights and hot
column5: long summers with occasional very hot temps
column6: unlike the surrounding coastal areas which are characterized by very mild winters and long warm summers. Most of the rain falls from October to January
column7: while the summers are very dry but not rainless. For its situation being inland
column8: the daytime temps are bigger than in the coast
column9: as well as the lows are cooler
column10: with a difference of at least 10 °C between the highs and the low temps during every month. The average annual temperature is 24.4 °C (76 °F) during the day and 11.9 °C (53 °F) at night. The average annual precipitation is 570 mm (22.4 in) per year
column11: concentrated in the months of October through April. December is the wettest month with 109 mm (4.3 in). The city averages 53 rainy days
column13: 965 hours of sunshine a year. Snow is extremely rare
column14: and it is even more infrequent than in most of the southern European islands. The last snowfall recorded in the city happened on February 2

Jerez has a reputation as the world capital of sherry wine. Sherry is a fortified wine made from white grapes grown near the town of Jerez. Jerez has been a centre of viniculture since the Phoenicians winemaking to Spain in 1100 BC. The Romans continued the practice after they took control of Iberia around 200 BC. The Moors conquered the region in AD 711 and introduced distillation
column2: which led to the development of brandy and fortified wine. Sherry became very popular in Great Britain. Because sherry was a major wine export to the United Kingdom
column3: many English companies and styles developed. British families founded many of the Jerez cellars.

column2: many of which are of British origin. The most important include:

column2: and his English agent
column3: Robert Blake Byass subsequently joined in. The firm produces the fino sherry Tío Pepe. According to the Guinness World Records
column4: the world's largest weather vane is located in Gonzalez Byass winery in Jerez
column5: Spain.

column1: Williams & Humbert: This is a winery located in Jerez de la Frontera dedicated to the production of sherry wines and brandies and other liqueurs. Sir Alexander Williams and Arthur Humbert founded it in 1877.
Grupo Garvey: William Garvey Power founded Grupo Garvey in 1780. As of 2018 it is considered one of the most important companies for wine

column1: Jerez is the original home of the Carthusian sub-strain of the Andalusian horse breed
column2: known as the Caballo cartujano in Spain. In the latter 1400s
column3: the Carthusian monks began breeding horses on lands donated by Álvaro Obertos de Valeto for construction of the Charterhouse of Jerez de la Frontera (la Cartuja de Jerez de la Frontera). When the Spanish Crown decreed that Spanish horse breeders should breed their Andalusian stock with Neapolitan and central European stock
column4: the monks refused to comply
column5: and continued to select their best specimens to develop their own jealously guarded bloodline for almost four hundred years.

column2: a riding school comparable to the famous Spanish Riding School of Vienna.

column1: Another famous equine institution headquartered in Jerez is the Yeguada Militar de Jerez de la Frontera (known outside Spain as the Yeguada Militar)
column2: the Spanish military stud farm dedicated to the breeding of purebred Andalusian and Arabian horses. Founded in 1847
column3: it became the official stud farm of the Spanish military in 1893.
